JPMorgan executive is first casualty of major blunder

In the wake of the bank’s $2 billion loss, JP Morgan Chase CIO Ina Drew, the person responsible for trading strategy, will retire, the bank said. (AP, 11:49 a.m.)

Court won't hear suits against FBI by alleged Bulger victims' relatives

The US Supreme Court has refused to resurrect lawsuits filed against the FBI by the families of two alleged victims of James "Whitey" Bulger. (Globe, 12:01 p.m.)

Judges: Keep jurors off Facebook

The Massachusetts Court of Appeals said judges must do more to inform jurors not to discuss cases over social media, which could risk a mistrial. (Boston Globe)

Massachusetts cuts county jails’ HIV programs

The state has eliminated more than $1 million for HIV testing and education in county jails, alarming sheriffs who fear the cuts threaten the health of inmates.

Women's progress in economics slow

Just one-third of PhD economists today are women, a percentage that has changed little since 1995, according to the American Economic Association.

E-retailer aims to up city's hip factor

Karmaloop, an online seller of so-called streetwear, is on a $200,000 mission to make Boston as hip as the clothing it sells.

City Council split over redistricting

Boston city councilors are divided over two plans for redrawing the nine City Council districts, although some still hope for a compromise.

Focusing on manufacturing’s future

At MIT last week, industry executives and academics met in an effort to devise improved industrial technologies and train better prepared workers.
Opinion | Juliette Kayyem

A crackdown avoided

In Mississippi, business interests thwarted a harsh bill on illegal immigrants.

More college presidents hail from outside academia

Twenty percent of college presidents in the US come from nontraditional or business backgrounds, up from 13 percent six years ago.

Nursing home abuses

The Globe's Kay Lazar reported that a high number of US nursing homes are treating patients with antipsychotic medications unnecessarily.

News

Plane crash kills 15 in Nepal mountains; 6 survive

A plane crashed into a mountain in the Himalayas while trying to land at an airport in northern Nepal on Monday, killing 15 people and injuring six, some critically.

Politics

Poll: Obama’s gay marriage stance aligns with youth, women

President Obama’s endorsement of legal same-sex marriage is likely to resonate with young voters and women, two blocs where Obama is already strong, a new Gallup poll indicates.

Business

Former Yahoo chief executive reportedly has thyroid cancer

Yahoo's Scott Thompson, who was pressured to give up his CEO post because his official biography included a college degree he never received, reportedly has thyroid cancer.
